title: Derry Girls Siobhan McSweeney criticises the DUP in Northern Ireland
text:
Siobhan has criticised the DUP (Picture: Anthony Harvey/BAFTA/REX)

Derry Girls star Siobhán McSweeney has called the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) ‘a party of bigotry, exclusion and ignorance’.

The Irish actress, best known for playing Sister Michael on the Channel 4 hit Derry Girls, has been vocal in her criticism of the DUP while campaigning for abortion rights in Northern Ireland, following the repeal of the eighth amendment in the Republic of Ireland last year.

And as the DUP urged the Stormont Assembly to be recalled in an attempt to stop the reform of NI’s laws on abortion and same-sex marriage, Siobhán feels ‘distraught’ for the North.

Speaking to Metro.co.uk at the Pink News Awards, the Cork-born actress said: ‘You can’t talk about Northern Ireland in isolation to any other part of the UK or the Republic of Ireland, and primarily it’s a question of the DUP. They seem to be the shaded part of the Venn diagram no matter which way you look at it, from Britain’s point of view or from the Republic’s point of view.

Siobhan has been vocal in her support for abortion reform in Northern Ireland (Picture: NIKLAS HALLE’N/AFP/Getty Images)

Ms Foster wants Stormont to sit before Monday to stop abortion reform (Picture: Danny Lawson/PA Wire)

‘What’s happening at the moment is, for me, quite simplistically – if people tell you who you are the first time, believe them. The DUP have repeatedly and consistently throughout their existence been a party and philosophy of bigotry, exclusion and ignorance, frankly.’

McSweeney continued: ‘I feel distraught for the people of Northern Ireland because not only have they been abandoned by Britain, they have been held hostage by the DUP, who have shown their colours. They’re willing to be sold. They are what they claim they’re not. They’re cheap and yet they’re also expensive – they can be bought.’

Leader of the DUP Arlene Foster has called for Stormont to sit before Monday, as same-sex marriage and abortion – which are currently illegal in NI – laws will change unless devolution is restored by 21 October.

The DUP has publicly opposed Westminster legislating on abortion reform.

Siobhan says that the Republic of Ireland have their own struggles (Picture: David M. Benett/Dave Benett/WireImage)

Today, Ms Foster announced that the party would not be backing Boris Johnson’s Brexit plans, saying: ‘As things stand, we could not support what is being suggested on customs and consent issues, and there is a lack of clarity on VAT.

‘We will continue to work with the Government to try and get a sensible deal that works for Northern Ireland and protects the economic and constitutional integrity of the United Kingdom.’

Siobhán also spoke of the struggles in the Republic of Ireland, citing British people applying for Irish passports in the wake of Brexit.

She said: ‘In the Republic, we’re struggling – absolutely we’re struggling. We have so many people coming from the United Kingdom who want Irish passports, and yet we have our own problem in the Republic where we’re not giving passports to the people who are actually Irish, as opposed to people who have an Irish history or legacy or whatever, who haven’t been brought up there.’

The actress said she was ‘proud’ to be at the Pink News Awards, saying: ‘It is a place where we can celebrate achievements that have been made in the most vulnerable parts of our society and the most neglected of our society. When it comes to Northern Ireland, the DUP perpetuate neglect.’

Held at Church House in Westminster, the annual awards saw speeches from Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn, outgoing speaker John Bercow, Shadow Women and Equalities Secretary Dawn Butler, MP Diane Abbott, Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer, MP Penny Mordaunt and Conservative Chairman James Cleverly.
